quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 7 Quiz 8
quiz.subtitle: 7.8: Ester & Amide Synthesis
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Synthesis methods for esters and amides using reactive derivatives

questions.question: Which of the following is the most reactive reagent for synthesizing an ester from an alcohol?
questions.explanation: Acyl chlorides are the most reactive derivatives; they react rapidly with alcohols at room temperature without requiring an acid catalyst.

questions.question: What is the byproduct formed when an alcohol reacts with an acyl chloride to form an ester?
questions.explanation: The chlorine from the acyl group and the hydrogen from the alcohol hydroxyl group combine to form $HCl$ gas.

questions.question: The reaction of an acid anhydride with an amine produces an amide and which other product?
questions.explanation: When the amine attacks one carbonyl of the anhydride, the other half of the molecule is expelled as a carboxylate/carboxylic acid.

questions.question: To synthesize $N$-phenylethanamide (acetanilide), which pair of reagents would be most effective?
questions.explanation: The reaction between a reactive acyl chloride and a primary amine is a standard and efficient way to produce a secondary amide.

questions.question: Why is a base like pyridine or $NaOH$ often added to the reaction between an acyl chloride and an alcohol?
options: To neutralize the $HCl$ byproduct as it forms.
To act as a dehydrating agent to remove water.
To oxidize the alcohol into an aldehyde first.
To prevent the ester from evaporating.
questions.explanation: The reaction produces $HCl$, which can be corrosive or cause side reactions. A base neutralizes the acid, driving the reaction forward.

questions.question: Which derivative is commonly used in the industrial synthesis of aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) from salicylic acid?
questions.explanation: Ethanoic anhydride is preferred over ethanoyl chloride in industry because it is less volatile, cheaper, and does not produce corrosive $HCl$ gas.

questions.question: The reaction of an excess of ammonia with an acyl chloride produces a primary amide and:
questions.explanation: One equivalent of ammonia forms the amide, while the second equivalent neutralizes the $HCl$ produced to form the salt ammonium chloride.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about using acid anhydrides for synthesis is TRUE?
options: They are slower than acyl chlorides but faster than carboxylic acids.
They require a strong acid catalyst to react with alcohols.
They produce water as a byproduct.
They cannot be used to make amides.
questions.explanation: Anhydrides are 'middle-ground' reagentsâ€”very effective and reactive, but more controlled and less hazardous than acyl chlorides.

questions.question: What type of amide is formed when a secondary amine reacts with an acyl chloride?
questions.explanation: A secondary amine ($R_{2}NH$) already has two carbons on the nitrogen; adding an acyl group ($RCO-$) makes it a tertiary amide ($RCONR_{2}$).

questions.question: Which reaction is the most direct way to prepare a primary amide?
options: Reaction of an acyl chloride with concentrated ammonia.
Refluxing a carboxylic acid with ethanol.
Reaction of an ester with a primary amine.
questions.explanation: The reaction between ammonia and an acyl chloride is rapid and yields a primary amide ($RCONH_{2}$) directly.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a great grasp of synthetic methodology.
scoreMessages.70: Great work. You understand the advantages of using reactive derivatives.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Pay attention to the byproducts formed by each reagent.
scoreMessages.0: Review the reactivity of acyl chlorides versus carboxylic acids.
